Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I tried to keep my voice steady as the customer on the other end grew more agitated, demanding to know why our offer was worth his time. My script was open in front of me, but my mind kept drifting to the text I’d just received from my sister—three words: “I need you.” She never said things like that unless it was serious. I could picture her, curled up on her bed, eyes red, waiting for me to call. But the customer’s voice snapped me back. “Are you even listening?” he barked. My manager expected me to handle objections, to keep the call going, to not let a long-time customer slip away. But my sister needed me, needed my comfort, my words, my presence. I felt the pressure building, my heart pounding as I tried to juggle the demands of being a reliable employee and a supportive sibling. I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, torn between the voice in my ear and the silent plea on my phone, not knowing which role to answer first.
